subject: Investing
title: Mean Reversion: Why Extremes Don't Last
description: A short lesson to help you apply Mean Reversion: Why Extremes Don't Last.

hook.text: The best-performing stock of the year rarely repeats the next year. Last year's winner is often this year's laggard.

buildup.text: Mean reversion is the tendency for extreme performanceâ€”good or badâ€”to drift back toward the historical average.

discovery.text: Sectors, countries, and individual stocks all show reversion patterns over 3-to-5-year periods.

twist.text: Investors chase recent winners expecting momentum. But momentum fades, and reversion sets in quietly.

climax.text: Rebalancing your portfolio systematically exploits mean reversion by selling high and buying low automatically.

punchline.text: What soars too high falls back. What drops too far rebounds. Markets obey gravity.

quiz.question: What is mean reversion?
options: Extreme performance drifting back toward the average over time
